DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text description and numeric percentage of the extent of the apocrine features associated with invasive cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Invasive Malignant Neoplasm Apocrine Differentiation Extent
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue._A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004_A morphologic finding that indicates the presence of cells with abundant eosinophilic and granular cytoplasm in a tumor sample._The range, magnitude, or distance over which a thing spans an interval of distance, space, or time.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
